Our attempts to maintain peace in the Persian Gulf through diplomacy have failed - $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ ships are already on their way to force the Hormuz Strait and punish us for our defiance.
We will defend our sovereignty, no matter the cost.

Our military forces have failed to defend the key outpost of Qeshm in the Hormuz Strait. The Qeshm Garrison, holed up in the Red Stone Fort and besieged by the European barbarians, eventually fell to thirst. Shekhbizin supremacy over the maritime routes in the Persian Gulf is now gone, and the Europeans are free to impose their terms - not only will we have to cede the island, but we will also not recieve single dinar of trade tax.
Qeshm eludes our grasp... for now.

Our recently established treaties with foreign powers have opened up commercial opportunities with the West. The flood of cheap manufactured goods from Europe, nevertheless, is strangling Iran's traditional artisanal economy and is increasingly placing us in a position of trade deficit. We might yet be able to use these commercial links with foreign markets to our advantage - by introducing cash corps to Esfahan. The province of Esfahan is largely barren and unfit for agriculture, with few fertile areas dedicated to the culture of wheat, barley and watermelons. Replacing these with Afyun, opium, could potentially result in much larger profits, allowing us to offset our negative trade balance.
We will encourage opium cultivation in Esfahan.
We will not allow such vices to fester in our realm.

Qeshm was our strategic commercial and military post in the Straits of Hormuz, controlling the flow of goods between Iran and the Indies and allowing us to project power on the squabbling Persian warlords. It seems, however, that we underestimated the endurance and obstinacy of the Persian people, who have defeated our garrison in Qeshm and, for over a year, repelled our attempts to bring it back under our control. With our resources now stretched thin, it might be time to come to term with the Persians and abandon our dreams of extending the reach of our Empire to the Arabian Gulf..
This barren rock isn't worth spilling more $COUNTRY_ADJ$ blood over.
Now that we have confirmed control over our rightful inheritance we shall grant the inhabitants of the Navarran lands citizenship.

Nomadism in the Zagros has its origins in the Mongol ravaging of Iran, when the destruction of the irrigation system forced the formerly sedentary Kurds and Lurs into migrational pastoralism. When the Timurtash Shahanshahs reunited Iranshahr, they could only exert limited authority over the Zagros tribes, relying on them for local administration and security of the western frontiers. In the aftermath of the fall of the Timurtash Dynasty, Luristan was formally ceded to the Ottoman Empire, although the Sultan never managed to control it - the expedition sent to assert Ottoman authority being crushed by a tribal coalition headed by the Shekbizin Kurds. The prestige from the victory against the Ottomans, combined with the capture of Isfahan and the cooption of the Qashqai in Fars, allowed the Shekbizin Khan to crown himself Shah. His position, however, has never been more than that of a primus inter pares - only Isfahan, Shiraz and Kerman being really under direct control of the crown.
Lurish autonomy will have to be tolerated, for now.

The Qashqai are a Turkic tribal confederation that migrated to Iran centuries ago. Settled by the Timurtash Shahanshah in Fars to protect the southern coastlines against incursions form the Spanish, the Qashqai have eventually come to dominate the military, economic and political life in the region. Their power resides in their ability to control the trade routes between the capital in Shiraz and Isfahan, and from then westwards into the Levant, and between Shiraz and Kerman and then eastwards into India. Acting as both toll collectors and military-security forces in Fars, the Shekhbizin Shah, whose capital resides in the heart of Qashqai territory, depends on the Qashqai Ilbeg's loyalty to rule.
We will need to stay on the Ilbeg's good graces.

The unwritten social pact between the tribal constituencies of the Shekhbizin Empire has all but broken down as the Shah has moved to curb the power of the local Ilkans and Ilbegs. The attempts to force the tribes to settle down have met with fierce resistance, as has the reform of the Shekhbizin army into a force composed of urban Persians loyal to the Shah, rather han Lurish and Qashqai soldiers with tribal affiliations. Throughout Luristan, Khuzestan and Fars the authority of the Shah is now void, and it seems that only the army can now restore order in the rebellious provinces.
The nomads shall be brought to heel in due time.

As the Shekhbizin Army moves South to stamp out the rebellion in the Lurish and Qashqai territories, the tribal forces prepare to meet the challenge, entrenching themselves in the mountain passes and trails where they are in their element. The Shekhbizin Shahdom, forged in the fire of the struggle against the Ottoman invaders, shall have to be reuinted in the field of battle as well.
Tribal interference with the affairs of the state ends now.
The Centralisation of the Shekhbizin Shahdom

As the dust settles over the battlefields in Luristan and Fars, the balance of power in the Shekhbizin realm has been definitively upturned, the Shah no longer having to accomodate and compromise with the tribal chiefdoms with which he had previously had to coexist in a precarious equilibrium of shared sovereignty. The cost of the campaigns has been great, and the outcome questionable - by forcing the tribes to settle down, the Shah has not created productive farmers, but rather starving nomads. The Shekhbizin enterprise has been rebuilt in the image of the Shah, and the tribes have paid the ultimate price.
Our authority is now uncontested and  unrivaled.

Worrying news are reaching us from Eriwan. Our presence in the city and surrounding territories has been compromised. There are claims that warriors have come from the mountains, set on resuming the work of their fathers during the Ottoman reign. Taking the war-banner of their martyr Joseph Emin, the Armenians have crowned one of their own, Hiovannes Beglarian, alowly noble from Karabakh as their new king and are now threatening to drive us out of the region! How are we supposed to react to this uprising?
They shall have their will, under the condition that their king bends his knee to us!
We must prepare to crush this insurrection!
Freedom for Armenia! Long live King Hiovannes!
The forces are finally ready to push into the Armenian highlands! News have it that the Armenian king has mobilised a small force of veterans and young volunteers to meet us in battle!
Let us drive these defiant peasants back into the mountains!

The Shaki hordes will soon fall upon our reborn kingdom. But we have resisted here for many years and we know where our fathers have kept their weapons and spoils of war. It is time to find our fortune in the mountains!
This stuff is old, but it will have to do!

Armenia is victorious! The foreign tyrants are driven out of our kingdom at last! The Shaki still continue to claim this land, but time will prove this claim to be void! It shall not sour this greatest victory of our people!

Armenia is victorious! Despite our best efforts we did not manage to retake the Armenian break-away state and have now been forced to recognise its sovereignity. But only time will tell If the Armenian dogs can manage to keep their kingdom together.

The Khanate is victorious! Erivan and all of Armenia are retaken and the head of the peasant-king on its way to the capital. Behold the spoils of war we have captured in the land of our enemies! Behold the heads of those who dared to resist!
When will they learn their lesson?

Many years have passed since the Shaki-Armenian War and yet our realm still stands, free from oppression and subjugation. The Khans on Shaki have failed to retake Armenia and few still recognise their claim to the heartlands. Now even they themselves have to acknowledge this! Despite all this they continue to claim the Zangezur-Corridor and seek to rule over the Turkomans that still live there. It appears that this matter will remain unresolved.
Nothing good will grow out of their stubbornness.

Many years have passed since the Shaki-Armenian War and the Kingdom of Armenia remains out of our reach. Our claim to Erivan and the surrounding territories has faded and even many of our nobles consider it to be a waste to clinge onto it. We will however refuse to leave our brothers in Nikchevhan to the Armenian dogs! So Allah will we are going be united with them once more in better days to come!
This is not over just yet!

The rise of Armenian nationalism has changed the face of eastern Anatolia forever. In our attempts to curb pro-Armenian sentiments, we were forced to use increasingly suppressive measures and while this was helpful at the time, it too could not halt the developments that we had long expected. With the ethnic violence between Turks, Kurds and Armenians seeing new heights in the eastern regions, the Armenians of Cilicia have banded together, formed a national assembly and decided to secede. We strongly suspect that they received help from Erivan, so if we decide to restore order in our rightful provinces, it will surely lead us into yet another conflict with Armenia. How are we to react to these developments?
Enough is enough! This act of rebellion must be dealt with swiftly!
Let them go. Maybe this will satiate the Armenians at last.

Our brothers in Cilicia have assembled and hunted the Turkish tyrants out of their land! Now the central government has ordered to restore order in the region. This will no doubt come with further repression and crimes against our kind. Should we announce our support to the new Cilician Republic?
How could we stay silent in the face of this? Send a delegation to Adana.
We cannot afford a conflict with the Turks right now.

Our brothers in Cilicia have assembled and hunted the Turkish tyrants out of their land! And for now the central government does not seem to be interested in reclaiming the territory. But it is only a matter of time until the Turks will try once more to subdue this new state. To that end the parliament of Cilicia has asked to be admitted into the Armenian state. Since the passes between our countries are still held by the Turks, an outright unification would be unfeasible, but we will be able to represent an autonomous cilician state on the world stage.

The Armenians have decided to aid the Cilician Republic in its unjust cause for independence! For too long have they been allowed to meddle in our affairs! This matter will have to be resolved on the battlefield!
It is time to teach them where they belong!

The war for Cilicia is won! For now we can celebrate, as more of our people have been liberated from their yoke. But it is only a matter of time until the Turks will try once more to subdue this new state. To that end the parliament of Cilicia has asked to be admitted into the Armenian state. Since the passes between our countries are still held by the Turks, an outright unification would be unfeasible, but we will be able to represent an autonomous cilician state on the world stage.
For now that is all we can do for them.
Now that we have established a permanent connection to the autonomous cilician province, there is little reason to ignore the wishes of its citizens. Shall we unite our two states?
We shall be one at last!

With the rise of Armenian nationalism and the creation of an expansionist Armenian state, the balance of power in Anatolia has been destroyed. The Armenians and Turks are now locked in a bitter rivalry and ethnic tension in both countries are at an all-time high. Our adversaries are now offering a population exchange to resolve this conflict for perpetuity. If we agree to their proposal, it would secure the status-quo, but take away the opportunity for expansion and the liberation of the lost lands of our people. Is this a price we are willing to pay?
The status-quo is unnacceptable! We refuse!
They accepted our proposal. Anatolia shall have peace at last.
Make sure that we fulfill our part of the agreement.
They refused our proposal. It seems that we will never reach an agreement.

The Naibs will certainly not give up their territories voluntarily. They must be convinced by whatever means necessary. The old freedom fighters would like to drive them out of the country, but such an act could provoke wide-spread violence and a drain of manpower into the Shaki Khanate. Another option would be to offer them and their retinue ranks in our military, akin to their positions in the Shaki forces. Some however argue, that their primitive training would set back our efforts in reforming our military. Of course there is also a great risk of integrating our former enemies into our armed forces, especially since a war with their kin beyond the border is not unlikely. Beyond these options, we could always buy the land of course.
Drive them out of our country by force!
Offer them ranks in our military.
Give them valuables in exchange for the land.
I think the status-quo is to be preferred over all of this.

The Kar-Kiya domains, stretching along the Gilani-Mazandarani shore of the Caspain Sea, are isolated by the Alborz mountains from the Iranian Plateau, and this inaccessibility has proved to be an asset to the Kiya Amirs - Timur, and the Timurtash Shahanshahs a century after him, prefered to delegate rule of this remote region to vassals amirs. Upon the collapse of the Timurtash Empire, the Kar-Kiya enjoyed newfound independence and even expanded south into the populous region of Ajam. Nevertheless, many wonder if the Kiya dynasty hasn't reached its high water mark. The recently ascended Rostam Kiya has inherited an ossified realm with paralysingly corrupt bureaucracy, deep economic crisis due to the disruption of trade routes with the West by the ongoing Janissary Revolt, and increasing religious unrest in Ajam as the Zaydi Shi'ite monarchy attempts to enforce its creed on a population split between Sunnism and the herectic Ismaili and Twelver sects of Shi'a Islam.

The Kalwatiya is a Sufi Order, a congregation of Islamic Mystics following a Shayk, a spiritual leader. Originally spreading from Eastern Anatolia through the Caucasus to Mazanderan, its eventual disappareance from the former areas and its persitence within the Kar-Kiya domains eventually led the Order, initially hostile to Shi'ism, to move closer over time to the heterodox Zaydi Shi'a tennets of the Kiya Amirs. The recent cataclysmic events within the Persian world - the Ottoman invasions, the fall of the Timurtash Empire and the subsequent conflicts between the new Iranian warlords - have, however, begotten a worrysome millennarian strain in the Kalwatiya. The Shayk has started to preach herectic concepts such as the transmigration of souls and the renewal of the cycle of time through the coming of the Mahdi, and the Order is starting to become a rallying point for the discontent elements of Kar-Kiya society, particularly in war-torn Ajam.
They shall have to be dealt with in due time.

The ripples of events in distant lands are starting to hit the Kar-Kiya domains, turning the intelligentsia in the realm against the monarchy. The German Revolution, although crushed 40 years ago, is still alive in the hearts of the Western Merchants purchasing silk in Rasht, who speak about its promises to overthrow despotism. The modernisation of Japan and its rise as a world power, capable of defying European imperial ambitions, also stirs the hearts of Kar-Kiya intellectuals, who resent the refusal of the Kiya Amirs to perform sweeping reforms to shore up the sagging Shahdom. All over the Kiya realm secret societies of intellectuals are organising, denouncing the decadent Arab influence on the Zaydi state religion and glorifying Iran's pre-Islamic past. Seditious talk spreads like wildfire as these societies encourage the disaffected subjects to throw off the Kar-Kiya yoke and liberate themselves through freedom of thougth and progress.
This traitorous talk cannot be allowed to spread.

The Olama, the Islamic clergy, have traditionally been close allies of the Kar-Kiya Amirs, sharing the common goal of strengthening the Zaydi faith. Nevertheless, in the context of the growing tension between the monarchy and reformists demanding for an end to the Amir's absolutist rule, the lower rungs of the Olama are increasingly siding with the intelligentsia. Although wary of the intellectual's secularism, many within the Olama see Constitutionalism as an opportunity to increase their sphere of power at the expense of the decrepit Kar-Kiya state, claiming the Kar-Kiya dynasty to be to weak to defend Zaydism..

The merchant class in the Kar-Kiya realm, once completely apolitical, is starting to embrace Constitutionalism as the cure for the economic woes that afflict them. The severing of the silk trade routes due to the Ottoman Civil War has led to Europeans seeking alternative sources in India, ruining the merchants whose livelihood dependend on this once lucrative trade. Moreover, the slowing of silk trade to a trickle has also deprived the Kar-Kiya of its main source of currency, leading to widespread inflation in the Shahdom. To compound these issues, Amir Rostam Kiya has started to favor Russian traders coming down the Volga in detriment of local merchants, and has even invited a group of Cossack adventurers to Lahijan to protect the growing community of Russian enterpreneurs. Whatever support the Kar-Kiya Dynasty might have once enjoyed in the Bazaars is evaporating by the minute.

The simmering tensions between the Amir Rostam Kiya and his subjects have finally erupted. The Amir's latest decree to further debase coinage - in a botched attempt to stem the currency shortage - has been met with outrage in the Lahijan Bazaar, where the merchants are joined by other Kar-Kiya subjects from all walks of life, denouncing the monarchy's inability to alleviate the inflationary crisis that threatens to sink the middle class into poverty and the lower class into starvation. The crowd then marches to the Yahya ibn Abdallah shrine, where the leaders of the merchant community write a manifesto demanding the end of despotism and the establishment of a Consultative Council, the Majles, to provide popular representation to all the social classes. With the Royal Army unwilling to fire on civilians in a Holy Shrine, Amir Rostam must make a decision: bow down to the popular demands, or turn to his only remainign support, the Russian quarter of Lahijan and its Cossacks.
Accept the demands of the Constitutionalists.
Unleash the Cossacks on the dissidents.

After a few hours of tense deliberation, Amir Rostam has finally decided to bow down to popular pressure and start the transition to a Constitutional Regime. A comission has been convenened, composed of members of the Court, merchants, intellectuals and the Olama, to write a Constitution, and a Provisional Parliament, the Majles, has been established in the Lahijan Summer Palace. Although many challenges lay ahead for the Provisional Government, hope returns to the Kar-Kiya subjects, who for the first time hold their future in their own hands.
Bloodbath at the Yahya ibn Abdallah Shrine

After a few hours of tense deliberation, Amir Rostam has decided that only through the absolute power of the monarch can the Kar-Kiya domain be held together. With the Royal Army mutinous, the Amir sends the Cossacks from the Russian Quarter, who show no qualms about massacring the Constitutionalists sheltering in the Yahya ibn Abdallah shrine. A precarious order is reestablished, but the brutality of the act and the reliance on foreigners has made Rostam's weakness nakedly apparent to everyone in the Kar-Kiya realm - including the Russians themselves, who might soon want to have their favour returned.

Shaik Zahed Rudbari, spiritual leader of the Kalwatiya, had patiently waited in the sidelines as the conflict between reformists and royalists played out. Now that the Constitutionalists have come on top, Zahed has finally decided it's time to mobilise his militant followers. Accusing the Provisional Government of ill-belief, and denouncing the proposed secular constitution to be incompatible with the holy Shari'a, the Kalwatiya march towards the Majles, the Parliament in the old Lahijan Summer Palace. A brigade of the old royal army, equipped with a single antiquated cannon, is sent to defend the Majles. The question is now whether the demoralised soldiers will stand fast, or will fail to defend the Constitutional Order just as they refused to shed their blood for Amir Rostam.
The Majles is reduced to rubble.

The violence in the holy Yahya Shrine is the final sign that Shaik Zahed Rudbari, spiritual leader of the Kalwatiya Order, was waiting for. Having already accreted a large following in the destituted classes, Zahed has gathered his devotees and proclaimed himself to be the reincarnation of Imam Zayd ibn Ali, the martyr who raised against the Umayyads and inspired Zaydism. The Shaik now intends to turn one of the core tenets of Zaydism against the Kar-Kiya: that Zaydis have the moral imperative to rise against illegitimate and corrupt rulers. Likening the Kar-Kiya Amirs to the Umayyad Caliphs, Zahed urges his followers to storm the Lahijan Palace and exact vengeance from the man responsible for their suffering and deprivations.
The Cossacks hold the line - the monarchy is saved.
The Kalwatiya capture Amir Rostam Kiya.

A handful of Daylamite Mountaineer soldiers with a single antiquated Light Howitzer is all that stands betweeen the Kalwatiya mob and the Majles. A tense confrontation ensues in the walls in front of the Old Summer Palace as Shayk Zahed's exhortations for the soldiers to lay down their arms fall on deaf ears - the Daylamites, belonging to the Ismia'ili sect, have little illusion of the fait that would await them under a Zaydi theocracy. The situation finally comes to a violent resolution as Zahed Rudbari orders his acolytes to storm the Majles and the Daylamites put their Mountain Gun to good use, firing grapeshot over open sights. Soon, all that remains of the mob is a mass of twitching, groaning bodies, including that of a barely-recognisalbe Zahed.

A handful of Daylamite Mountaineer soldiers with a single antiquated Light Howitzer is all that stands betweeen the Kalwatiya mob and the Majles. After tense negotiations, the soldiers agree to abandon the gun in exchange for keeping their rifles, as well as safe passage out of Lahijan. The Kalwatiya acolytes immediately put the Mountain Gun to use, bombarding the Old Palace now serving as the provisional seat of the Government. The bombardment is brief, but effective - the members of the Majles that aren't killed soon surrender. Shayk Zahed Rudbari is triumphant, and the Kalwatiya become the new masters of the former Kar-Kiya domains, establishing a theocratic regime with Zahed as spiritual and political leader of the Zaydi faithful.
The ill-believers have recieved their due.

The Cossacks try to mount a desperate defence of the Royal Palace with the little means they have available - the royal army by this point having largely evaporated and deserted after the massacre at the Yahya Shrine - in face of the Kalwaitya mob assembling in front of them. Having failed to requisition a Mountain Gun from a fleeing army unit, the handful of Cossacks decides to stand fast and try to fend off the fanatics with their rifles, knowing the grim fate that awaits the Russian Quarter of Lahijan should the Kalwatiya succeed. The Shayk finally orders his acolytes to charge, and although many are cut down, the Cossacks are eventually overrun. Amir Rostam Kiya is captured, beaten to death by the mob and his body is thrown into the Lahijan river. A new regime begins, with Shayk Zahed as Nuqaba, the perfect Zaydi leader, and the Kalwatiya initiates as Nujaba, those called by God, replacing the upper Olama as civil and religious authority.

The Cossacks try to mount a desperate defence of the Royal Palace - having disarmed a deserting army unit, they now find themselves in possession of a light field howitzer. As the Kalwatiya acolytes assemble in front of the walls of the palace, there is little hesitation in the Cossack commander's mind, knowing that a takeover of the Kalwatiya would result in the pillaging of the Russian Quarter of Lahijan. The Mountain Gun is promptly put to use against the mob, which hurriedly scrambles as soon as the shrapnel starts to mercilessly rain on their heads. The body of Shayk Zahed, bloodied and barely recognisable, is hanged in front of the Lahijan Congregational Mosque as a reminder of the consequences of challenging the rule of the Kar-Kiya monarchy.

Months of heated debate have followed the establishment of the new Constitutional Regime, which up until now lacked a proper Constitution to buttress the new order and delineate the divisions of power of the Kar-Kiya society. The Olama, the court, the intelligentsia, the merchants - all have tried to extract concessions from the others in an effort to either maintain or obtain privileges. The end result is a document that doesn't fully satisfy anyone, yet it provides a common ground upon which a joint national project can be built.

News are reaching our borders that the para-military Anjomans have broken and taken control of the government in $FROMCOUNTRY$. Having operated for years in the shadows, undermining the authority of the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ government through a mixture of violence and persuasion, the Anjomans have finally decided to come out in the open and stage a coup. On account of our dominant position on the Iranian plateau, the newly formed government in $FROMCOUNTRY$ sends word that they accept $COUNTRY$'s natural position as the legitimate leaders of the newly formed State of Iran..
Sign a Treaty of Friendship with Russia?

The Cossacks under the command of the Russian adventurer - and self-proclaimed protector of the Russian merchant quarter of Rasht - Konstantin Alexeyev were instrumental in stiffling the Constitutionalist unrest and crushing the Kalwatiya Uprising. Alexeyev was, however, just a private individual acting on his own accord, for Russia was still too fragmented in bickering principalities, and the Tatars still posed a considerable threat, to think about diplomacy across the Caspian Sea. Now that the Russians have united under the rule of a single Tsar, nevertheless, it would be in our best interest to establish formal diplomatic relationships and sign a Treaty of Frienship and Commerce, and propose Alexeyev as a candidate for the ambassadorship to Lahijan.
We're better off on our own.

Diplomats coming from the faraway lands of Persia, across the Caspian Sea, have just reached the Court of the Tsar of All Russias. It seems that news of the proclamation of our Empire are spreading across the Orient, inspiring both awe and fear. The Persian diplomats come with a proposal to sign a treaty of Friendship and Commerce, and to set up a Cossack adventurer already established in their capital as the Russian ambassador. Trade with the Iranians in the southern shore of the Caspian could prove to be very lucrative - we would be able to import valuable silk, rice, fruit and spices, while exporting fur, amber, leather and various metallurgic products.
We shall never treat them as equals.

Our diplomats have just landed in Rasht after returning from their diplomatic mission to the Russian Empire. It seems that the embassy has been an unqualified success, with the Russians recognising us as a legitimate government and as their favoured trading parters south of the Caucasus. Konstantin Alexeyev has been appointed as the Russian consul in Iran, formalising his role as leader of the fleding Russian community in our realm.
May our business bring us both prosperity.

As the Russian Empire expands and its might becomes overawing, it is clear that the only jewel that is fit for the Tsar's crown is India, a land of untold riches contested by the European Great Powers. Whereas the Empires in Western Europe have already established a presence in India from the sea, our path towards it must inevitably cross Central Asia. We have already established cordial relations with a Persian dynasty on the southern shore of the Caspian Sea, a friendship which we could use to our advantage. We will request a 10-year lease of the city of Gorgan and the adjacent port of Bandar Torkaman, paid for in advance, in return for the establishment of a joint military mission to modernise the Persian armed forces. The possession of Gorgan will open us the door to Khorasan, from where we will be able to march across the Hindu Kush towards the promised treasures of India.
Approach the Persians to lease Gorgan.
We have no time for Imperialistic games.
Russia Proposes the Lease of Gorgan

The Russian ambassador in Lahijan has just presented a proposal to cede Gorgan, as well as its nearby Caspian port at Bandar Torkaman, for a 10 year period in exchange for a hefty downpayment and the establishment of a joint military comission to modernise our army. We are now faced with a dilemma: accept the proposal, stay in Russia's good graces and take the opportunity to bring our armed forces up to Western standards - or refuse, at the risk of incurring the Tsar's wrath, knowing that the lease of Gorgan might only be the first step of an Imperialistic project that might include not only India but Iran as well.
The Persians Refuse to Cede Gorgan

Our proposal to lease Gorgan has been rebuked by the Persians, complaining, perhaps not without justification, that to cede Gorgan would mean adding another competitor for the dominance of Khorasan, which the Persians recently fought a war over. It is clear that if we want to subjugate the Persians, words will not suffice.
We shall teach them a lesson.
This backwater port is not worth war.

Ten long years have gone by since we decided to lease Gorgan and the port of Bandar Torkaman to the Russians. At the time, the deal looked advantageous, and indeed we have put this decade of cooperation with Russia to good use, modernising our army to European standards. Nevertheless, the lease didn't include a prorogation clause, and we have no intention of negotiating one - Gorgan must be returned to its rightful owners.
The Russians must hand over Gorgan.
The Persians Demand the Return of Gorgan

Persian diplomats have recently brought to our attention that the contract signed between both nations for the lease of Gorgan, over a decade ago, has expired, and that the Persian Shah does not want to negotiate an extension of the lease period. It would be honorable to respect our mutual agreement and hand the Caspian port back, but doing so would mean giving up on a strategic outpost for our Indian designs. Gorgan is the key of the routes travessing Mazanderan towards Khorasan, and Khorasan is the path towards the coveted heart of India.
We will be true to our words.
The Russians Dig In around Bandar Torkaman

Our diplomatic mission to the court of the Tsar has returned bringing bad news: the Russians refuse to peacefully hand Gorgan to us, and are willing to use force to keep it. Already, the Russian forces garrisoning the Bandar Torkaman port are reported to be digging trenches, and rumours abound that Russian sailboats are dropping infernal devices in the shallow waters in front of our Mazanderani ports - naval mines, explosive devices against which our modest navy has no recourse. Conflict is all but inevitable.

The campaign in Persia can only be descirbed so far as an unmitigated disaster, with no signs of improvement on the horizon. Many of our soldiers, completely unfit to the hot and humid climate of the southern Caspian shore, have succumbed to disease, and the Persians have stormed our forts at Gorgan and the port of Bandar Torkaman. It is time now to lay down our arms and seek a diplomatic end to this embarassing affair before the honour of the Russian army is further besmerched.
The Spectre of Jihad in the Caucasus

Our territories on the northern side of the Caucasus are recent acquisitions, the result of our irresistible expansionist drive of the past decades. The population has proven to be hostile to Russian rule, stopping short of open rebellion. Now, however, Iranian agents acting in Dagestan have successfully lighted the fuse in the powderkeg: the Shayk of the Naqshbandiya Order has rallied the tribes of the Caucasian Muslims and has declared Jihad to expell us from their lands.
We shall crush them as well.

The young Kingdom of Macedonia has recently signed an armistice with the Ottoman Empire, signalling the end of a long struggle for independence against Turkish oppression. As the guns fall silent, the intrinsic contradictions of the new state become apparent - a Kingdom trying to balance the national aspirations of both Greeks and Bulgarians, with a Catalan King at the helm whose regnal name, Alexander I of Aragon-Makedonías, evokes the ancient glory of classical Hellenism. Nevertheless, the triumph of Macedon over the Turks is a clear message of hope to all the Greeks elsewhere who yearn for self-rule, including those within our realm.

Salonika has fallen, bringing an end to the Aragonese venture to carve out a friendly Kingdom in the Balkans and to the hopes of Greeks and Bulgarians to throw off the Turkish yoke. Martí Ferran Alfons, erstwhile Alexander I of Macedonia, has narrowly managed to escape from the advancing Turkish troops and sail back to Barcelona under the protection of Aragonese warships. As the latest attempt to create a Hellenic state in the Balkan fails, the Greek population of the Venetian Stato da Màr increasingly looks at Catholic rule as a necessary evil preferrable to Turkish conquest.

It all started with the exhortations of an Orthodox priest in Trikala, encouraging the parishioners to avenge the atrocities commited by Ottoman troops in Salonika during the Macedonian War of Independence. Looting of Turkish commerces followed suit, and local Muslim notables were rounded up, tortured and executed in the Trikala Market Square. Ethnic violence against Mulsims has spread like wildfire throughout Thessalia as our troops, for now, remain on the sidelines. We could order our Garrisons in the area to stop the violence, at the risk of incurring Greek enemity, or allow them take part in the rioting, pleasing our less scrupulous soldiers looking for a cut of the Turkish loot. Alternatively, we could sit by and let the violence burn itself out.
We must protect the Turkish civilians.
Let the riots run their course.
Allow our troops to loot to their heart's content.
The Turks Hang the Patriarch of Constantinople

News of the violent riots and pogroms against ethnic Turks throughout Thessalia have been met with outrage at all levels in Constantinople. Eager to exact some measure of vengance, the Turkish state has found a convenient scapegoat in the form of the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, Cyril VII. Claiming that, as Ethnarch of the Greeks and spiritual leader of Greek Orthodox Christianity, Cyril is accountable for the acts of Greeks, even those in the Venetian Stato da Màr, the Patriarch has been put through a show trial and shortly afterwards hanged in front of the Church of St. George.
This will surely inflame our Greek subjects.
Found the Scola Superiore di Commercio

The Mazor Consegio has decided that part of the yearly budget should be allocated towards building a new University to foster the pursual of higher education in our Republic. To make this expenditure more palatable to the more recalcitrant oligarchs, the institution will be called the Scola Superiore di Commercio and will, initially, be dedicated exculsively to economic studies, with a view towards eventually expanding to a full-fledged University. The question remains on where the Scola should be built. We could choose to build it in Venice, making our capital a true metropolis dominating not only the political and economical arenas but also having preeminence in the academic field. Alternatively, we could build it in Athens as a concession to our restless Greek subjects and as a homage to the splendour of Classical Greek philosophy and mathematics.
Venice, we will renovate the old Palace of Ca'Foscari.
Athens, we will build a completely new University right by the Acropolis.
In the aftermath of the opening of the Council of Athens, a Provisional Government is established in mainland Greece, for now tolerated, if not recognised, by the Republic of Venice.
We will see where the negotiations take us.

The struggle for Freedom against Venice is proving to be a tough one, our young Republic lacking the resources necessary to decisively drive out the forces of the Serenissima from Hellenic soil. What was initially envisioned as a short, triumphant revolutionary uprising has degenerated into a prolonged conventional war in which Greece's chances of coming out on top look increasingly slim. In this desperate context, some in the Provisional Government are proposing to enter a personal union with our northern neighbour, Macedonia, in exchange for them declaring war to Venice. Although this proposal has been met with outrage by the Zimisces and his followers, many others are starting to see it as a necessary evil to ensure the survival of Greek statehood.
Propose a Greco-Macedonian union after Independence is won.
We won't betray the spirit of the Greek Revolution.
Greece Pleads for Help against Venice

Revolution has spread throughout the Morean Domains of Venice, resulting in the establishment of an independent Greek Republic in the mainland territories of the Venetian Stato da Màr. With both sides unwilling to find a peaceful solution ot the crisis, the confrontation has inevitably sled into armed conflict. For now, the Kingdom of Macedonia has stayed neutral, but recent news regarding Venetian massacres of Greek civilians in the Attican town of Oropos are making this stance increasingly unpopular with our Orthodox subjects. Now the Greek Provisional Government itself is crying out for help - proposing that the King of Macedonia recieve the additional title of King of Greece, in exchange for Macedonia entering the war on the side of the Greek revolutionaries.
The Hellenic people shall be free from foreign domination.

The Macedonians have accepted our proposal for a Greco-Macedonian Union and are already sending troops down south to bolster the beleaguered forces of Greece. Discussions about the nature of the proposed Union have been postposed until the war with Venice is concluded, the Greek Provisional Government being completely divided on the issue of how tightly Greece should eventually be tied to Macedonia. But this is a problem for the future - right now Greeks and Macedonians are brothers in arms united in the struggle to end the Venetokratia once and for all.
Together we shall finally throw the Venetians out of Greece.

Now that the guns have fallen silent in the Morea and Attica and the Venetians have been forced to recognise the Independence of the Greek Republic, the thorny quetion of the promised Greco-Macedonian Union has once again come to the forefront. Macedonia declared war against Venice under the understanding that once peace was reached the Greeks would recognise Alexander I as Basileus. Nevertheless, the Greek Provisional Government is divided on the Macedonian Question - some politicans argue that such a move would ensure the freedom of the Greeks in the face of Turkish and Venetian revanchism, whereas the influential military faction led by Zmisces clamours that selling away the hard-fought Independence would be the blackest treason.
We will accept Alexander I of Aragon-Makedonías as King of Greece.
We are altering the deal - we will not give up our Indpendence.

The Greeks have kept their promises and, now that we have vanquished Venice from the Morean battlefields, we shall be joined together in a perpetual dynastic union. Alexander I of Aragon-Makedonías becomes King of Macedonia and Greece and thus the leading regional power in the Balkans.
All Greeks will eventually become our subjects.

Greek Independence was bought with Macedonian blood and sacrifice under the agreement that, once the Venetians had been dealt with, Greece would come under the fold of the Macedonian King. Yet the Greeks have renounced on their war-time promises, claiming that under no circumstances are they willing to exchange one foreign ruler for another one. Once borthers in arms, Greeks and Macedonians now become enemies as the Macedonians prepare to turn their arms agains their erstwhile allies.

The war against Venice has brought our young realm to the brink of bankruptcy - the absence of farmers to work the fields, the lack of an indigenous armament industry worth the name and the strains caused by the Venetian blockade all bringing our economy ever closer to collapse. The minister of finance of the Provisional Government is proposing that we look at one of the leading European powers, Burgundy, for economic assistance. In the recent years Burgundy has invested heavily into Greek agriculture, drawn by the prospects of profit to be made with Corinthian raisins to supplement the domestic wine production, failing due to grape bight. If we can convince the Burgundian government that an independent Greece would be willing offer more favourable trading conditions than the Venetians, we might recieve the necessary financial aid to shore up our sagging economy.
We will ask Burgundy for help.
We can manage on our own.

It has been a year since the Greeks rebelled against their Venetian overlords, and the violence shows no sign of abating. Many within the Burgundy landowning class are sympathetic to the Greek cause - due to their Classical upbringing, but also due to their investment into Greek agriculture to import Corinth raisins. With grape bight devastating vineyards all over Burgundy, wine made form Corinth raisins has emerged as an acceptable substitute. We could send financial aid to the Greeks, although doing so would damage our long-standing commercial ties with the Serenissima.
Venice is a more reliable trading partner.

Burgundy has agreed to aid us in our struggle to free ourselves from the Venetian yoke - they will provide a long term, low-interest loan, the payments for which won't start until an armistice is signed. Additionally, the Burgundians have pledged themselves to provide arms to the young Hellenic Republic, leveraging their economic power to allow overland transport of military goods through neutral countries, thus bypassing the Venetian blockade.

The Burgundian government has politely refused the overtures of the Greek diplomats to secure arms shipments and financial aid for the struggle against Venice. The long-standing commercial ties with Venice have taken precedence over any dreams of philhellene adventures, and our main economic incentive, trade of Corinthian raisins, has lost its allure after the succesfful import of Arcadian grapes to Burgundy to overcome the wine bight.

Although the Burgundian loan has helped prolong our war effort, our resources are being strained to the breaking point by the war against Venice. The minister of foreign affairs of the Provisional Government is proposing to make overtures to Aragon, a traditional rival of Venice in the Mediterranean. Moreover, Aragon has a history of Balkan meddling, having installed an Aragonese prince as King of Macedonia and provided military aid in the Macedonian and Albanian Wars of Independence. We could offer the Aragonese to lease rights to the use of military ports in the Adriatic, allowing them to place their fleet within striking distance of the Straits of Otranto and therefore threaten Venice's maritime lifeline.
We will ask the Catalans for help.
We don't need more foreign mercenaries milling around.
Intervention in the Greek War of Independence?

Greek diplomats from the as-of-yet unrecognised Hellenic Republic have reached out to us, proposing to lease ports in the Adriatic in exchange for military intervention in the ongoing War of Independence against Venice. Conflict with Venice would undo years of diplomatic rapprochement with our long-time rival for domination of the Mediterranean - yet the allure of adventure in the Balkans is strong, evoking images of the glorious times of Roger de Flor and the Almogàvers. Having a friendly government ruling over Greece would cement our position as the power-broker of the Balkans, and perhaps more importantly, victory over Venice could be the solution we have been looking for so long to stiffle the nationalist tensions between Catalans and Italians in the Miezzojuorno.
We don't need more trouble in the Italian peninsula.

The Aragonese have wholeheartedly accepted our proposal, and have declared that a state of war exists between the Crown of Aragon and the Venetian Republic. Although the struggle will still be strenuous, the Greek people can look at the future with a glimmer of hope of the Venetian blockade being broken and Aragonese troops landing in mainland Greece.

The Aragonese have refused to take military action against Venice. Although the Catalan monarchs are sympathetic to our cause, the Aragonese Crown finds itself in a delicate situation in both mainland and insular Sicily, where simmering Italian nationalism threatens to erupt into revolution. Entering war against an Italian power, the Catalan diplomats claim, would be akin to the self-immolation of Aragon.
The War of Independence Reaches Its Second Year

It has been two long years since the Greek people rose as one to overthrow the despotic rule of the Venetians. Much has been sacrificed in the name of freedom and, as the terrible conflict enters its third year, it seems clear that still much martyrdom still lays ahead for the Hellenic people.

After three years of conflict agains the rebellious Greeks, we must finally come to accept that Hellas is lost. All the Venetian garrisons in the fortifications along the Morean coast have been starved into surrender, our amphibious expeditions have met with varying degrees of disaster and the rebels can boast undisputed control over all of mainland Greece. We must negotiate peace, acknowledging reality as unpallatable as it might be. Although there is not much room for negotiation, and surely we will have to give up the Morea and Attica, we might yet be able to keep hold of Crete and the Aegean islands.

Epirus and its mixed Greco-Albanian population has been the source of much tension with our southern neighbour, Greece. The Greeks are now proposing to settle this issue once and for all, deporting Albanians south of the former administrative limit of the Sanjak of Yanina to Gjirokaster. We shall do the same: deport Greeks north of the new boundary to make room for the mass of incoming refugees.

The Albanians have shown themselves to be receptive to our proposal to exchange minorities on both sides of the Epirote border, and trains are already being organised to bring the Hellenic Orthodox population south into our domains.
Now that we have reclaimed Taurica for Hellas, it is time that we rename the major cities and landmarks to the names that our ancestors gave them.
The Proclamation of the San Marco's Republic

Our recent defeat at the hand of the Greek rebels has laid bare the inadequacy of our merchant-oligarchic form of government to face the challenges of the modern era. Venetian politics in the past decades have been increasingly polarised around irreconciliable postions: those who saw Venice's future as a Mediterranean nation of nations, and argued for closer cooperation with the Greeks, and those who claimed that in order to survive, Venice need to centralise its power structures and become a unitary Republic. Now that we have lost most of the former Stato da Màr, the balance of power has decisively shifted to the centralists. Venice will be reorganised into a parliamentary Republic and its energies will be redirected to the Italian peninsula in hopes of harnessing the rising waves of Italian pan-nationalism.
A new beggining for the Serenissima.

The Crown of Aragon has been steadily declining over the course of the past decades, their grip on the Miezzojuorno becoming increasingly precarious in the face of rising Italian nationalism. Moreover, our old treaty of friendship with Aragon has proven to have no real value - the Aragonese did not intervene on our side during the Greek Rebellion, with the consequence of the loss of our possessions in Attica and the Morea. It is now our time to become the overlords of the Italian peninsula, taking over the role that Aragon is unfit to fulfill. We will host a new Council of Italy, proposing the unification of the peninsula to the fragmented states that are currently vulnerable to foreign exploitation. Where Etruria failed, we shall triumph.
We shall be masters of Italy.

Our first round of diplomatic contacts to discuss the possible unification of Italy will take place with the various Republics of the peninsula. Sharing the same democratic principles as we do, they are the most likely to see the benefits of federating into an Italian Union to defend the principles of liberty, fraternity and equality.
The Second Council of Italy: the Venetian Proposal

The Venetians have organised a Second Council of Italy, presenting unification as the only way to preserve the Italian way of life in the face of foreign encroachment. Undoubtedly the Venetians would be at the helm of the proposed pan-Italian state, and we must decide whether this is preferrable to continued domination by the Catalans and the Anglois.
We won't give our Independence away.

Our next round of diplomatic contacts to discuss the possible unification of Italy will take place with the various non-aligned states of the peninsula. Being the most vulnerable to fall victim of the power plays between Aragon and the Anglo-French Monarchy, we hope that they see the benefits of federating into an Italian Union to finally spare the Italian people of the devastation of the foreigner's wars.
The Final Proposals of the Second Council of Italy

Our final round of diplomatic contacts to discuss the possible unification of Italy will take place with the states that are currently tied with varying degrees of subservience to foreign powers. Although they have limited room of manouver, their foreign policy being practically dictated from abroad, we will promise to help them in case of Imperialistic aggression.
The Second Council of Italy: the Venetian Proposal

The Venetians have organised a Second Council of Italy, presenting unification as the only way to preserve the Italian way of life in the face of foreign encroachment. Undoubtedly the Venetians would be at the helm of the proposed pan-Italian state, and we must decide whether this is preferrable to continued domination by the Catalans and the Anglois.
We won't give our Independence away.
The Closing of the Second Council of Italy

As the Second Council of Italy closes, we must look at the future with hope. Our diplomatic entreaties have met with mixed results: some states have agreed to be integrated into our realm, while others have refused to see the light and remain alone and frail. Nevertheless, we have come out of the Council recognised as the foremost power of the Italian peninsula and the only one legitimised to rule over the Italian people - a fact not lost upon the Dual Monarchy and the Crown of Aragon, from whom we must expect retaliation in the near future.

The Arvanites are an Orthodox people speaking a non-normative Albanian dialect, and have populated for centuries Attica and the Morea, being a majority even in the newly re-founded capital of Athens. In spite of their language, the Arvanites identify fully with Greek Orthodoxy and the Greek nation, yet some in our government see them as a threat to our nascent nation and a source of potential conflict with Albania. Proposals are being put forward to implement a policy of Hellinopoieisi - forced Hellenisation. The Arvanites would have to swear an oath not to speak their language, not even in the domestic sphere, as the first step towards building a healthy Hellene national consciousness. Arvanite language would be banned in schools, Greek schools for adults would be opened and government officials would be sent to Arvanite localities to ensure the proper implementation of Hellinopoieisi.
We won't discriminate our Arvanite brothers.

The ailing Khalil Khan is but a shadow of his former self, disease steadily eroding the man that became the master of the Caucasus. Once a vassal petty Khan of the Timurtash Empire ruling over a small domain in the Kura river valley, Khalil exploited the power vacuum left by the Timurtash collapse by conquering the petty Khanates from Baku to Tabriz. With death creeping every closer to the Khan, succession must be secured, and a decision has to be made between his sons Ibrahim and Ahmad. Ibrahim is a proven military commander, who proposed and led the invasion Gorjestan in the aftermath of the Ottoman Civil War, and sees the Khanates future lying north of the Greater Caucasus Range. Ahmad, on the other hand, has inherited the boundless ambition of his father, seeking a prize even greater than what his predecessor achieved - the vacant throne of the Iranian Shahanshah.
Favour Ibrahim Bey, the subjugator of the Kartvelians.
Follow Ahmad Bey's dreams of becoming the Shah of Shahs.
The Montafeq Overthrow the Shekhbizin Shah

The disintegration of the Shekhbizin Shahdom has been a long time coming, defeat after defeat shrinking the Shekhbizin domain until losing its powerbase in the Zagros and being pushed altogether out of Iran. Its last remaining territories in the marshlands of Basra were recent conquests, the result of a campaign to subjugate the Montafeq Arab tribes. Never fully acknowledging the sovereignity of the Shah, the Montafeq have now overthrown the Shah and shattered any illusions of continuing the dynasty in Iraq.
Arabs shall no longer be slaves to Persian masters.

Upon the death of the last great Timurid emperor, Shah Rukh, the empire splintered into rivaling states - Babur Mirza in Khorasan, Ulugh Beg in Transoxiana and Sultan Muhammad in Ajam. Babur recruited the Timurtash, a Turkmen tribe headed by the ambitious Khan Qutlugh, ostensibly to fend off Uzbek raids, although soon they would become an essential component of his military forces, employing them to crush Sultan Muhammad. Soon after they were tasked with facing Ulugh Beg, who crossed the Oxus southwards to restore order to his father's realm. In the ensuing battle, Ulugh was forced to retreat and faced the usurpation of his son Abd al-Latif, who blinded him. Babur marched north to conquer Samarkand, but the siege of prolonged into a hard winter. Qutlugh harnessed discontent in the army to rebel, proclaiming the blind Ulugh as Shah and becoming the power behind the throne. After the death of Ulugh Beg in 1456, Qutlugh crowned himself as the first Timurid Shahanshah.

The disastrous defeats against the Ottomans, the Dzunghar conquest of Transoxiana and the rebellions of Kurdish tribes and Zaydi notables in Western Iran brought about the near collapse of Timurtash central authority. The Empire only managed to hold on to a very reduced territory in Khorasan through bribing the local nobility, the Dehqans, through the granting of extraordinary privileges, the Soyurghal. The Soyurghal is a system of land grants in which the holder of the appanage has the right to control taxes and muster local military forces, while enjoying almost complete immunity to judicial interference from the Imperial centre in Herat. While decentralising the state and empowering the Dehqans might have prevented total disintegration of the realm, the Shahanshah Firuz II now finds himself nominal emperor over a collection of increasingly independent-minded Dehqans, and even his brother Idris is refusing to pay the annual tribute corresponding to his appanage in Marw.
We shall restore central authority in due time.

Our forces have reconquered Bukhara, a key trade node in the route from Khorasan through Soghdiana and eastwards towards the Ferghana and China. One of the earliests conquests of Qutlugh Shah, under the Timurtash Bukhara experienced a second golden age, with Imperial patronage making New Persian literature flourish and the building of a dense network of irrigation canals finally allowing the city to recover from the devastation it had suffered during the Mongol invasion. Bukhara also became home to Islamic mystics, the Naqshbandi Sufis, which cemented the city's status as the epicentre of Islamic enlightenment. Lost to the Dzunghars in the closing years of the 18th Century, its recovery will greatly increase our standing among our subjects and - most importantly - the Dehqan nobility.
The Ka'ba of the Empire is ours once again.

The great metropolis on the Zarafshan, Bukahara, has been abandoned by our retreating forces. Being the undisputed cultural centre of our Empire, the loss of Bukhara can only be interpreted by our subjects as a further step in our steep decline, and a sign to the Dehqans to demand more autonomy and privileges from the weakened Shahanshah. While our Empire managed to survive the loss of Bukhara decades ago to the Dzunghars, many doubt that it will be able to do so again.

The entry of Firuz II into Isfahan marks an upward swing of fortunes for the Timurtash dynasty. Isfahan had traditionally been a key outpost to project Timurtash rule in the Western half of the Empire, allowing the Shahanshah in far-away Herat to maintain a modicum of control over the frontier territories of Khuzestan and Azerbaijan. The vizerate of Isfahan was one of the most coveted administrative posts in the Empire, and although the last vizier remained loyal after the disastrous defeat against the Ottomans, he was soon overthrown by a Kurdish warlord with imperial ambitions. With Isfahan back in our hands, it should be clear to the Dehqans in Khorasan that it is in our power to rebuild a proper centralised administration.
Our grip on Western Iran is strengthened.

As our forces burn the last remaining bridges over the Zayandeh Rud, dark clouds loom over the Timurtash Empire once more. The loss of Isfahan, for the second time in less that half a century, burns down any dreams Firuz II might have had of re-establishing a solid imperial grip over Western Iran. The local gentry of Khorasan, the Dehqans, now face a real threat to their appanages - and this fear can only worsen the centripetal tendencies that Firuz II's weak rule has begotten.

The inhabitants of Shiraz greet our troops with showers of flowers plucked from the city's flourishing gardens, welcoming the return of Imperial rule with joy. Shiraz was where the second Timurtash Shahanshah, Abdurashid I, dealt the death blow to the crumbling realm of the Aq Qoyunlu Sultan Khalil Mirza, paving the way for the conquest of Western Iran. With Shiraz back in our hands, we can coerce the Qashqai Confederacy into a degree of submission to extend our rule to the rest of Fars. Moreover, we are now in a position to control the caravan routes going eastwards towards India and southwards towards the Persian Gulf, reducing our economic dependence on the unreliable contributions of the Khorasani Dehqans.
The City of Gardens is back in our hands.

The irrigation canals that feed Shiraz' splendid gardens now run red with the blood of our massacred troops, routed out of the city and expelled out of Fars altogether. The loss of Shiraz is a devastating blow to the treasury of the Timurtash dynasty, and many now fear that the already demoralised army might be fertile ground for mutinies if the soldiers' salaries are not paid in time. Firuz II's control over his remaining territories totters as he will now inevitably have to depend on the goodwill of the Dehqans to be able to maintain anything resembling a military force on the field.

Our troops have reconquered Lahijan, the historical seat of the Kar-Kiya Amirs, effectively destroying any remaining legitimacy that this dynasty might still have left. The Kar-Kiya were one of the many vassal states that the Timurtash relied on to control the Western reaches of the Empire, too remote be effectively placed under direct control of Herat. The Kiya Amirs enjoyed great autonomy, and were allowed to freely practise the Zaydi branch of Shi'a Islam, following the Timurtash tradition of religious tolerance. Nevertheless after the collapse of the Western frontiers and the Ottoman invasion, the Amir Rostam II rebelled and started to conquer former Imperial territories in Ajam. This betrayal has now been avenged, and we have gained control over a strategic node in the trade route of silk through the Caucasus and across the Caspian Sea towards Europe.
The Gate of Europe is back in our hands.

Our troops scramble across the bridges over the Sefid Rud, having suffered a defeat so complete and humiliating that the provinces of Gilan and Mazanderan will have to be altogether evacuated. The loss of Lahijan is a blow to the prestige of the Timurtash royal house and exacerbates the economic throes of the Empire, now cut off from the trade of textiles with the West. The position of Firuz II is significantly weakened in relation to the Khorasani Dehqans, who are eager to exploit this weakness to their benefit.

Our troops stop for prayer in the ruins of the Blue Mosque of Tabriz after a victorious campaign. Tabriz was once the cornerstone of Timurtash military strategy in the Caucasus, acting as the logistical base which fed the armies that confronted the Ottoman Empire and the political centre from which the vassal Khanates of the Caucasus were kept in check. Upon the annihilation of our armies in our last campaign against the Ottomans, Tabriz passed to Turkish hands in the Treaty of Qarabagh, although the Janissary Revolt meant that they never exercised actual control. The ambitious Khan of Shaki, Khalil Khan, conquered Tabriz in the early decades of the century and effectively ended any Ottoman pretenses of dominating the Caucasus. With Tabriz back under Timurtash control, it becomes apparent to our subjects as well as to our enemies that our military has recovered from its nadir and is once again a force to be reckoned with.
The Throne of the Ilkhanate is back in our hands.

Our forces evacuate Tabriz, and with it any hopes of extending Timurtash rule to the old Caucasian frontier. Moreover, Imperial rule over Ajam is now vulnerable and the notables of the Empire now fear of an invasion through Tehran and Qumis towards Khorasan, the heart of the Empire. The loss of Tabriz accentuates the localism among the Khorasani Dehqans, who will now be less likely to willingly contribute military forces for campaigns far away from their appanages.

Herat, the Pearl of Khorasan, the centre of the Timurtash Empire for almost four centuries, has been lost to enemy forces. Under the Timurtash Herat experienced a period of continued economic growth and political stability, becoming a bustling metropolis whose renown was celebrated across the Muslim East. The Timurtash Empire managed to survive the loss of most of Western Iran in the early 19th Century by falling back on its core territory of Khorasan, with Herat still at its centre. Now, however, with the Imperial capital gone, the dynasty has lost more than just a city - it has lost the heart and soul of the Empire, the remaining pillar which sustained and legitimised Timurtash rule. With the petty Dehqans increasingly disregarding the authority of Firuz II, it seems that the history of the Timurtash Empire will soon reach its final violent conclusion.
The Writing is on the Wall.
The Persecution of the Ismaili Da'i

Ismailism is an esoteric branch of Shi'a Islam that postulates that Ismail ibn Jafar was not dead, but rather in occultation, by the time of his father's death and therefore is the rightful 7th Imam. Although Ismailism has drastically receded since its apogee during the Fatimid Caliphate, the Ismaili remain a vibrant community in Iran, having significant presence in Ajam, Daylam and Khorasan. Ismailism has been traditionally tolerated by the Timurtash Dynasty and the Da'i, Ismaili missionaries, have been given a free hand, being seen as yet another offshoot of Sufi mysticism. War, defeat and deprivation, nevertheless, have created a climate hostile to Ismailism. Although the royal family still maintains its tolerant tenets, the legends of Ismaili Assassins have made the Da'i a convenient scapegoats in the violent landscape post-war Khorasan, where murder is now a political tool often employed by generals, Dehqans and the Olama.
We can't let the Dehqans choose our realm's religious policy.

Our efforts to centralise the Timurtash Empire and reestablish a true bureaucratic administration are being met with fierce resistance from the Dehqans. The discontent of the landed magnates is being harnessed by three military governors - Ali Bulend in Golestan, Nasr Mihirabani in Nishapur and Behar Kaskar in Kohestan. The three warlords are the holders of the largest Soyurghals within the Empire and have been at each other's throats for years competing for the coveted Governorship of Khorasan, compounding the already crippling ungovernability of the provinces west of the Murghab river. In spite of their bitter rivalry, the three army leaders have forged an unlikely coalition, finding common ground in opposing Firuz II and his progressive dismantling of the Soyurghal system.

In the middle of the night during a hunting expedition, Firuz II, Shahanshah of the Timurtash Empire, wakes up to find his two tame lions mauling an armed intruder. In his dying breath, the wretched man reveals that he was paid by the slave of a magnate to assassinate the Emperor. Investigation quickly uncovers a chain of corruption leading to a coalition formed by the three military governors of Khorasan with the backing of the majority of the Khorasani Dehqans, both groups resenting the centralist policies enacted by Firuz II which have eroded their privileges and autonomy. As news of the plot's failure spread, the military governors of Khorasan - Ali Bulend, Nasr Mihirabani and Behar Kaskar - mobilise the military resources of their respective Soyurghals, preparing for the inevitable punitive expedition from the Imperial Centre in Herat.
War Looms Over Khorasan Once More

Over the past few months all links between Herat and the rebellious military governors have been severed. The amirs appointed by the Shahanshah in Gorgan, Nishapur and Birjand have been executed by the rebels, who are now starting to stamp their own names over Timurtash currency and are massing their military forces for a joint march on Herat. While they might disagree on how to proceed after an eventual victory, that is a problem for the future - for now, they have Firuz II Timurtash as a common enemy binding them together. All that remains to be seen now is whether the Shahanshah will stand and fight, or if he will surrender the crumbling remains of his Empire to his power-hungry governors.
We will remove these pretenders from power, by force.
We are too weak to intervene. Khorasan is lost.
The Struggle for Supremacy in Khorasan

Khorasan descends in chaos as the three former military governors of the region, Behar Kaskar, Nasr Mihirabani and Ali Bulend not only fight against Firuz II Timurtash but also against each other. Years of dammed rivalry finally erupt into open warfare between the holders of the largest Soyurghals within the former Timurtash domains.
Death Knell for the Soyurghal System

The rebellion of the military governors of Khorasan has been crushed and the provinces west of the Murghab have been brought under direct Imperial control. Any Dehqans that supported the uprising have had their lands requisitioned and, pending a cadastral survey of the former Soyurghal lands, will be redistributed to small proprietors which will form the nucleous of a new landowning class loyal to the Emperor, rather than to the feudal lords. The Khorasani warlords were the holders of the three largest Soyurghal grants in the Empire, and with them out of the picture, there is now little to hinder the Shahanshah in the hollowing out of Dehqan privilege and eventually the outright abolition of the appanage system.

The mountains in the province of Nishapur are dotted with mines exploiting turquoise deposits of the highest known quality. These mines have been operating for millenia, its heavenly-blue stones serving to decorate tiles in palaces, domes in mosques and as jewelery exported to the remotest confines of the known world. Several villages in the province bear the name Madan - mine, in Persian - reflecting their nature as miner settlements. The war against the Dzunghar Khanate greatly disrupted the turquoise trade, and the bankruptcy of the state precluded the necessary maintenance work to keep most mines operating at full capacity. Now that the Timurtash realm is recovering, we could invest in re-activating the mining sector in Nishapur - draining the waterlogged galleries, clearing the debris in caved-in tunnels and rationalizing the layout of new shafts and chambers to be dug.
Agricultural production should be our focus.
The Restoration of the Timurtash Empire

The Timurtash Empire, not so long ago on the brink of total collapse, has finally reasserted its mastery over all of Iran. The Shekhbizin Kurds, which had taken over large swathes of southern Iran and claimed legitimacy after defeating an invading Ottoman Army, have been relegated to the ash heap of history. The Kar-Kiya, once loyal vassals ruling over Gilan and Mazandaran, have been finally expelled from Ajam and removed from power in their Caspian homeland. No one can contest now the facts on the ground - the Timurtash are once more masters over all of Iran between the Amu Darya to the Aras rivers, between the Caspian Sea and the Persian Gulf.

Nasir Kushraw was a Khorasani poet and philosopher who lived in the tumultuous world of XI Century Iran. He traveled far and wide, eventually coming to the domains of the Fatimid Caliph, were Kushraw converted to Ismailism. Kushraw returned home to spread the Ismaili faith, but was met with virulent hostility from the Sunni authorities that governed Khorasan at the time. Fleeing to the remote region of Badakhshan in the Pamirs, Kushraw would accrete a large following among the local Pamiri population, who still venerate him to this day. Moreover, the account of his travels, the Safarnama, is still regarded throughout the Persian-speaking world as one of the greatest works of Iranian literature.
We must take pride in such heritage.

The Tarim Basin, also known as Moghulistan, had been for centuries the domains of the Yarkand Khans. As their authority was progressively eroded over time, the Khojas, Sufi leaders belonging to the Naqshbandi Order, became the power behind the throne, governing in the Khan's name. This arrangement continued after the Dzunghar conquered Moghulistan, with the Khojas paying tribute to the Oirat Töra. After the implosion of the Dzunghar Khanate, the Khojas created their own independent theocratic state, which we now neighbour after our reconquest of Badakhshan and the Ferghana. The Tarim has traditionally been a site of strife between competing Empires and an essential node in trans-Eurasian trade, and on its Western end lie a series of mountain passes through which invasions could be mounted on Transoxiana. We should send an ultimatum to the Khojas to submit to us - before the resurgent Chinese or Mongols beat us to it.
The Khojas will have to acknowledge our overlordship.
Our current border is safe enough.

Timurtash diplomats from across the Pamirs have been agitating for closer ties between Moghulistan and Iran for months. Citing security concerns over the possiblity of Chinese or Mongol invasions through the mountain passes in the Pamir and Tangri Tagh ranges, the Shahanshah is demanding that the Yarkandi government be fully aligned with Herat, ceding control over matters of defense and diplomacy. But what last week were strong suggestions, now is a clear-worded ultimatum: join Iran in a pact of "mutual self-defense" or face the armies of the reborn Timurtash Empire.
We will bow down to the will of the Shahanshah.
We will beat the Iranians just like we beat the Oirat.
The Khojas Bown Down Before the Timurtash Throne

The Turki Khojas, fearing an Iranian invasion that might devastate their young state, have agreed to become vassals of the Timurtash Empire. The Naqshbandi Khojas will continue to rule autonomously over the oasis cities of Moghulistan, but from now onwards defense and economic policy shall be dictated directly from Herat.

The Naqshbandi Khojas ruling Moghulistan have tried to play a delaying game, hoping to desist our diplomatic efforts to solve the question of the Pamiri border and its military ramifications. The time for negotiations is now exhausted and, our ultimatum not having been answered satisfactorily, we have no option but to order our troops to invade the Tarim Basin and secure the mountain passes in the Pamir and Tangri Tagh by force.
We will order our armies to march on Moghulistan.
The Tarim is but a glorified desert anyway.
The Lease of Kashgar and Tashkurgan

The Khojas of the Tarim were forced into tributary status to secure the mountain passes that lead to the rich regions of Transoxiana, a backdoor through which to attack the Timurtash Empire. The current arrangement, however, is still insufficient to Timurtash military planners - they demand that Kashgar and Tashkurgan be placed directly under Iranian administration. Tashkurgan controls the routes going from the Amu Darya to Moghulistan, whereas Kasghar is an oasis located at the very centre of the trans-Eurasian trade networks, serving as an obligatory stopping point for merchants traveling from China towards Sogdiana and Iran, or southwards across the Karakoram into Kashmir and India. Controling both locations would greatly improve our hold on Central Asian trade as well as providing strategic depth for a possible invasion from the East.
The Fortifications of Kasghar and Tashkurgan

Tashkurgan and Kashgar were brought into our Empire to secure our Eastern borders, yet the current fortifications in both places are but a heap of ruins. Tashkurgan sports a ruined stone fort from antiquity, whereas the once mighty city walls of Kashgar are in a state of disrepair after the final war between the Dzunghar Khan and the Khojas. To make them into efficient defenses suited for modern warfare, these fortifications will need to be practically rebuilt from the ground up, with smaller interconnected strongpoints supported by cupola-protected guns replacing the current stone buildings which could not withstand the fire of even the lightest artillery pieces.
We will invest into modernising the forts.

The province of Azarbayjan and its capital of Tabriz have seen better days - three major destructive earthquakes throughout the 18th Century, looting during the Ottoman Invasions and neglect under the administration of the Turkoman Khans have left the civilian infrastructure of the region in a state of decrepitude. Even the emblemic Blue Mosque, a marvelous piece of Qara Qoyunlu architecture, is now but a heap of ruins. Through a programme of intensive state investment, we might be able to restore Azarbayjan to its former glory, repairing roads to facilitate trade, rebuilding the ruined bazaars that once housed a vibrant merchant community and assessing any damage on extant structures to prevent catastrophe in future earthquakes.
We will make Tabriz the jewel of Iran.
We can't afford such a great investment.

The Ossetians are the descendants of the Alans, the great Iranian nomads who dominated the Pontic Steppes in antiquity, eventually migrating during the Dark Ages as far west as the Atlantic shores of Lusitania. The Alans that remained behind in their steppe homeland were eventually pushed into the northern Caucasus by successive waves of Turkic invasions, where they have survived nowadays as the Ossetian people. With Gorjestan securely under our control, it is our duty to push northwards of the Caucasus and liberate our cultural kin from their current state of national opression.
We will embrace them into our realm.

Last night Firuz II, Shahanshah of the Timurtash Empire, passed away in his sleep. The man leaves behind him a troubled legacy of struggle against the centripetal forces that threatened to disintegrate his realm, conflict with the Dehqans over the attempted centralisation of the Empire and the failed dream of restoring the Empire to its former position as the preeminent power in Iran. As questions over succession arise, many now start to debate even the future of the monarchy itself in the face of increased regionalism and the dissolution of traditional bonds between the Timurtash royal house and the landed nobility which had hitherto kept the realm together.
We mourn the for man, and the Dynasty as well.
Requiem for Firuz II the Restorer

Last night Firuz II, Shahanshah of the Timurtash Empire, passed away in his sleep. The King of Kings earned his epithet, 'the Restorer', owing to his success in bringing the Timurtash Empire from the edge of the abyss and turning it into a modern, centralised state dominating Iran and capable of defending its frontiers against foreign encroachment. While many doubted upon the accession of Firuz II that he would be able to live up to his name and rebuild the broken Empire that his father had bequeathed him, few now doubt that his successor inherits a realm headed into an age of prosperity.

The textile industry has pioneered the modernisation of the Chinese economy from handcrafting into machine-made mass-produced goods. Although there is a growing number of mills and spindles set up throughout China, the industry will not be able to take off and reach its full potential unless we enact an energetic policy of state investment into cotton production and protect the domestic production by increasing tariffs on foreign cotton piece goods. Failure to properly support the cotton industry could have deep repercussions on China's ongoing modernisation process and prevent our nation from truly flourishing.
Tea export is too valuable to be replaced.

Spain has declared the Treaty of Selon void, removing any legal impedement for European powers to wage wars of expansion in the East Indies. Burgundy, Scandinavia and the Dual Monarchy of England and France had shown increased assertiveness in ignoring the terms of the Treaty, prompting Spain to take up its role as Protector of the Indies to an unprecedent level. The natives can now expect Spanish rule to acquire a much more direct character.

With central authority in Persia and the Ottoman Empire nearly non-existant, the Kurdish people must now fend for themselves, pushing out foreign plunderers. As a reaction to the chaos, a host of Kurdish militia-men, known as the Kuren Kurdistana Azad has joined arms to fight for that cause.
