The ruins indicate that the city used to be protected by a wall and was built around a cenote, which might have been the key religious and ceremonial centre of the region. Unlike any other archaeological sites found so far in Yucatán, Mayapan is abundant with colonnaded halls engraved with both Classical-era Maya motifs as well as Aztec-style feathered serpents.
A glorious day for the Maya!
The Legacy of the Chichimeca Wars

The Otomi people perhaps more so than any other Mesoamerigan people has shown remarkable resilience over the centuries, resisting assimilation first under the Aztecs  who gave them their current name after the Nahuatl word for wanderer, Otomitl - and later on under the Spanish colonialism. Nevertheless, the Otomi now live in geographically fragmented communities and, though most of them were reunited after the War of Independence, the Guanajuato Otomi still live outside of the Confederation. This community is the legacy of the Chichimeca Wars, in which the Otomi sided with the Spanish in an expedition to put an end to the raids of the nomadic Pame tribes. In the ensuing campaign the Pame were vanquished and their lands settled by Otomi ranchers, though they were soon outnumbered by Castilian colonists. With the Independence of the Confederation, it is only just that the Otomi claim whats theirs by right of conquest.

The government campaign to drive out the caciques has not yielded the expected results  although the caciques themselves have been defeated and formal village governments have been set up another group, the clergy, has taken up their role as oppressors of the Otomí peasantry. The religious caste is keeping a stranglehold on village life through a reinvigoration of the cargo-system, a hierarchic framework of offices which effectively perform the functions of the local government. Although service is theoretically voluntary and any villager can serve in any office, the clergy is using coercion to force participation and to keep themselves at the cuspid of the pyramid. For the villagers participation in the system effectively means a steady drain of their scarce financial resources to fund religious rituals, which in turn keep the clergy as the group monopolising wealth and political power in the village.
We shall deal with the clergy in due time.

After the War of Emancipation, the Mixe came to be ruled by one of the most eccentric figures of current Mesoamerigan politics  Calixto Chapital, a minor noble during viceroyal times who became during the Revolution the dominant strongman in Sierra Madre de Oaxaca. Not a man to hold back his ambitions, Calixto crowned himself King and claimed to be the heir of Kondoy, the mythical King who legends say has been watching over the Mixe since time immemorial. Despite these lofty claims and an extravagant crowning ceremony in Mount Zempoaltepetl, the reality is that Calixtos mestizo descendancy and colonial origins are sagging his legitimacy. The King has no choice but to court the loyalty of a powerful cacique, Aguilar Eneedzaa, who holds the office of Minister of Development. For now, Eneedzaa seems to busy himself with a far-reaching programme of alphabetization  although many point out that one of the key points of the programme, indigenism, might be targeted against Calixto.
Coffee Plantations in the Mixe Lands

The Minister of Development and second most powerful-man in the Mixe Kingdom, Aguilar Eneedzaa, has taken it on himself to bring the backward economy of the Sierra kicking and screaming into the modern age. Being an hacendado on his own right and owner of extensive coffee plantations, Eneedzaa is abusing his office to force farmres in the region to cultivate coffee on pain of imprisonment and is even willing to go as far as forcing the students that fall under his jurisdiction to cultivate coffee without compensation. Although the export of coffee will certainly shift the foreign trade balance of the Kingdom towards the black, the means are deplorable and it is hardly a secret that under the current arrangement Eneedzaa holds a monopoly on the transport of the exported coffee.
A cup of deep black Joe please.

The explosion of coffee cultivation promoted by the Ministry of Development has led to a spike in the number of labourers being employed in the Mixe plantations. The minister himself, Aguilar Eneedzaa has recognised the need to unionise the farmers, leading to the creation of the Union of Mixe Peasants to protect the rights of the labourers and negotiate advantageous deals with Zapotec merchants in the lowlands. These commendable intentions are, nevertheless, no more than a cynical cover  in practise, the Union has so far only worked towards supressing peasant wages and recent reports seem to indicate that Eneedzaas men are starting to round up labourers for coerced work in the Haciendas of local caciques.
Road Building in the Sierra Madre

Although efforts have been made in recent years to modernise the economy of the Mixe lands, one inescapable obstacle has hindered all efforts to date  the Sierra Madre de Oaxaca, which stands in the way of the flow of goods towards the Zapotec merchants in the Central Valley. The Ministry of Development has correctly identified the need to carve a modern road along the Sierra to improve the abysmal infrastructure of this crucial trade route, but its methods are causing much disquiet among the Mixe population. Press gangs organised by Minister Eneedzaa prowl the villages that straddle the Sierra, forcing men to work in exchange of promised tax exemptions.
At least the wagons run on time.

Though the cacique Eneedzaa and King Chapital had managed to cooperate up to this point, recent developments have shattered the fragile equilibrium that kept both men in check. Having been at the helm of several ambitious projects to modernise the economy and infrastructure of the Mixe country, Eneedzaa no longer feels the need to cultivate royal patronage and has started to build up his existing power base into a parallel state apparatus. Most concerningly, Eneedzaa has recently organised the so-called Social Defence Brigades, effectively an army loyal to him outside of state control, and has directed them to expand his area of influence through naked violence. The Brigades have been targeting villages loyal to the Royal house, terrorising the local population into submission and making an example of those who refuse to break their oaths to Calixto Chapital  reports speak of one stalwart Mayor whose tongue and soles were cut off. Civil War looms.
Civil War in the Mixe Lands

It seems that the crisis in the Mixe lands will be solved through the same nefarious tool which has unfortunately been resorted to time and again in the past years: assassination. The royal troops sent to arrest Aguilar Eneedzaa on grounds of graft have been repelled outside of his Hacienda and the fighting, carried out by Mixe soldiers none too willing to engage in a fratricidal struggle, has devolved into a low-intensity siege of the plantation. King Chapital has started contacts with members of the personal staff of the cacique, hoping to bribe one of the servants into poisoning Eneedzaa. Nevertheless, the cacique is unlikely to stay put either and rumours are circulating that a plot is hatching within the inner circle of the King to remove Calixto Chapital.

The Republic of Ndua represents a true watershed in the history of the Zapotec history, being the first truly independent Zapotec state since the fall of the Zaadxil dynasty at the hands of the Spanish conquistadores. Though the Zapotecs can pride themselves in being the heirs to one of the great Mesoamerigan civilisations, the current state of affairs in Oaxaca  or Ndua, as the Zapotecs call it  does not leave much room for optimism. Centuries of colonialism made Zapotec labourers reliant on the capital of criollo creditors to finance the production of Nduas most precious export, red cochineal dye. After independence and the abolition of the colonial Repartimiento system which fuelled dye production, the economy of Ndua has steadily declined and the Zapotecs, once one of the most enterprising peoples of Mesoameriga, now face the prospect of systemic economic failure.

Vanilla came to dominate the Totonac economy during colonial times: its use as a source of flavour for beverages was recognised early, but the industry only truly came on its own once the consumption of chocolate exploded in XVII Century Europe. This enterprise brought great wealth to Totonacapan, with Totonac cultivators and traders having the advantage of being close to the only export node of vanilla in New Spain, Veracruz. Nevertheless, the plantations suffered greatly during the upheavals of the Wars of Independence and Emancipation, though the heaviest blow actually came from the primary importers  a Burgundian botanist devised a method to pollinate vanilla flowers by hand, therefore bypassing the need to cultivate the plants in the presence of native Mexican insects. Through the use of this technique the production of vanilla has been exported to the tropical colonies of Burgundy and the Dual Monarchy, where they are outcompeting the hapless Totonac planters into poverty.
We must seek a way out.
The Left Bank of the Amazon

In the aftermath of the secessionist movements in the former Viceroyalty of Granada several rebellious provinces have declared independence, leaving our exclave in Pará an isolated exlcave. Given the current inability of Gran Colombia to defend or exploit this backwater territory, influential groups in the Congress are starting to lobby for a sale of this malaria-stricken jungle to a southern neighbour either affluent or foolish enough to meet our financial demands.
We could perhaps sell the land.
We shan't yield an inch of Colombian land.

The Gran Colombian government, having lost control of the lands south of Andagoya, has made an offer to sell the exlcave they currently possess in Pará, along the left bank of the Amazon river. Although this land is currenlty underdeveloped and will likely become a financial burden in the short term, owning both banks of the Amazon would be highly desirable from a strategic point of view.
We don't need any more frontier troubles.
